phrase: **H**ydrant. *Blue* for "first place" (blue ribbon) and for water, its principal compound; tall and thin, shaped like a "1". Hydrant sounds like hydrogen (both refer to water).
**He**lium Balloon. *Silver* colored for "second place" (silver medal); a noble color for a noble gas.
**Li**thium watch battery, 3-volt. *Lilac* colored (sounds like lithium and all three natural minerals are lilaccolored).
**Be**ryl-studded **Be**lt Buckle. Rectangular (4 sides), with four *pink* beryls (beryl is a pink gem: beryllium aluminum silicate).
**B**ox of **B**orax. 5-pound box, *dark brown*, the color of pure boron (borax is hydrated sodium borate).
**C**harcoal pencil. *Black*, the color of charcoal and also of graphite (carbon) in pencil leads. Hexagonal (6-sided).
Dynamite, or **N**itroglycerin. Two *red* sticks, shaped like a "7" (most explosives contain nitrogen).
**O**xygen-filled Lifepreservers. *White* for air, which preserves life. Two of them touching, shaped like an "8".
**F**luoride Toothpaste. *Purple*, the color of the mineral fluorite (calcium fluoride), and shaped like a "9".
**Ne**on Sign. Shaped like a "10", flashing *orange*, like the orange/red color of neon in neon signs.
**Na**rrow Soda Crackers. Two of them, bright *yellow*, shaped like an "11", like the bright yellow sodium D spectrallines. Sodium is named for soda (sodium carbonate).
**M**u**g**. 12 oz. *green* mug made of olivine (magnesium silicate), filledwith milk of magnesia (magnesium hydroxide). Magnesium in chlorophyll gives plants their green color.
**Al**uminum Ladder. Unlucky to walk under, and 13 is unlucky. *Turquoise (blue-green)* colored (turquoise is hydrated aluminum phosphate).
**Si**licon Chip. It as 14 pins, and is the *tan* color of sand (silicon dioxide) or sandstone (silica).

**P**hosphorus Matches. *Red/white* striped book of 15, heads white, striker red (there are both white and red forms of phosphorus). The matches could light the dynamite (nitrogen) in the periodic table.
**S**ulfuric Acid. One pint (16 oz.), *pale yellow* in a flask.

**Cl**orox. *Yellow-green* bottle, the color of chlorine gas ("chloros" means yellow-green in Greek). **Cl**eans 17 ways (Clorox is sodium hypochlorite). Note that Clorox has no letter "h" making it easy to remember the abbreviation Cl.
**Ar**gon-filled Fluorescent Light. 18-inch, *sky-blue* (air is 1% argon).

**K**ettle, or *Pot* of *gray* *Ash*es. 19th-century way to make soap from potash (potassium is  named for potash, potassium carbonate or hydroxide, which is named for the pot of ashes used to obtain it).
**Ca**lcite Pearls. *Ivory* A string of 20 pearls. Calcite is a form of calcium carbonate.
**Sc**andal Page. One should be 21 years old to read the scandal page of the newspaper.
**Ti**tanic. The Titanic had 2200 passengers when it hit an iceberg and sank.
Che**v** Van. 23-passenger van made with vanadium steel.
Chrome-plated **Cr**eamer. 24-oz. pitcher of cream.
Autu**mn** Mangos. 25 of them.
**Fe**rris Wheel. 26-seats and made of iron. Sounds like "ferrous", which refers to iron.
**Co**bblestone. It is a 3" cube, so it has a volume of 27 cubic inches.
**Ni**ckel. In 1928, the year before the Great Depression, people had more money (a nickel) than in the next year ('29). The U.S. coin called a "nickel" used to be made of nickel.
Copper Penny. The **Cu**rrency during the Great Depression which began in '29.
Bra**z**e**n** and zinc sink. Made of galvanized iron (iron coated with zinc), with $30 brass (brazen means brass) faucet. Brass is an alloy of copper and zinc. Sink sounds like zinc.
**Ga**lleon. The old Spanish galleons had three masts, each of which looked like a "1", to remind us of 31.
**Ge**rman beer. A quart stein (32 fl. oz.) of German beer. Germanium was named for Germany.

**A s**kull & crossbones. Rat poison is arsenic trioxide, commonly called simply "arsenic". In other forms, such as is found in apples, arsenic is nutritious. Arsenic has three natural varieties: black, gray and yellow, as shown by the three colors in the icon.
**Se**nsitive solar *cell lean*ing. Leaning at a 34° angle off vertical. Sounds like selenium. Solar cells often contain selenium.
**Br**oom. 35 Bristles (seven rows of five). In the periodic table, note that all the elements in this column are cleaners.
**Kr**ypton Yardstick. One yard is 36 inches. Krytonn gas is used to define the scientific unit of length, the meter, which is about a yard long.
Supe**rb** ruby. *Red* ruby, 37-carat.
I**sr**aeli Strongbox. Bright red because the red in mostfireworks is from strontium. It weighs 38 pounds.
A Tree. **Y**-shaped, with a "39" carved in it. Sounds like yttrium.
E**zr**a's **Z**ircon **R**ing. Only cost $40.
U**nb**earable Onion. "For one" person only. Sounds like Niobium and like "4,1". In Greek mythology, Niobe wept for the loss of her children, like an onion makes you weep.
**Mo**lly's Denims. 42" waist. Sounds like Molybdenum.
Du**tc**h Technician. 43-years-old. Technetium was made synthetically; it is not stable enough to be found in nature.
**Ru**th's hen. It's feet look like 44 and "Ruth's hen" sounds like Ruthenium. It is also by the wren and ostrich in the periodic table.
Road in **Rh**ode Island. Speed limit 45 m.p.h.
To**p d**og **P**alace. The sultan has 46 wives in its 46 towers, which look like "46".
**Ag**nes's Silver Dime. '47 was **A G**ood year after WW II. (Silver is "argentum" in Latin).
**CD** Caddy. The caddy holds 4 dozen (48) CD's.
India **In**k. 49 cent bottle.
Tin Can. Contains 50 **Sn**ails. Tin cans are made of steel sometimes covered with a thin layer of tin.
Ant money. Taking **s**mall **b**ills ($5 and $1) to its pas**sb**ook account.
Deck of 52 Cards. *"**Te**ll your"* fortune (sounds like Tellurium).
**I**odine. Bottle costs 53 cents.
Zenith television, watching "**Xe**na". On channel 54; a TV tube contains xenon gas.
**C**esium **S**tandard Clock. A physi**cs** clock. It reads 5:05; time to go home.
**Ba**d Berries. Poisonous. About 5/6 of all white berries are poisonous (really). Black are usually edible.
**La**ntern. 57 candle-power.
**Ce**real bowl. Has 58 nutrients.
**Pr**aying mantis. Eats 59 bugs.
**N**o **D**im Lights. Triangular sign has 60° angles. Bright lights can bli**nd**.
Prominent fire. Fire is needed after 6:10 **p.m.** Promethius brought fire to mankind. The flames look like 61.
**Sm**all samurai  sword. 62 generations of use.
**Eu**ropean rope (63 feet long).
Ma**gd**alene's Cattle. "Cattle" sounds like "gadol"inium. Checkerboard pattern (a checkerboard has 8x8 = 64 squares).
Brigh**t b**lue turban. 65" long.
Dan**dy** disposal. Disposes garbage in 6.6 seconds.
**Ho**me. This home has room for 6 or 7 children.
H**er**b (Erbium Er). The stems and leaves form a hidden 68 in the picture.
Chris**tm**as Tulip. Red and green for Christmas. 69 kinds.
Lad**yb**ug Litterbag. A litterbag (small portable trash bag), which sounds like Ytterbium, with a ladybug picture on it with 70 spots. Litterbags were popular in the '70s.
**Lu**te (Lutetium Lu). 7 Strings on 1 Lute (71).
Fait**hf**ul Half Dollar. 72 is half a gross (of 144). Also, there are 72 ounces of silver in $100 of silver halves (or quarters or dimes). The ones dated 1964 or earlier are silver.
**Ta**n **Ta**ll Man. He is 7'3" tall basketball player.
**W**estinghouse light bulb. 74 **W**att, with tungsten filament. Another name for tungsten is Wolfram, which explains the abbreviation.
W**re**n. Visualize 75 of them on a telephone line.
**Os**trich. 7'6" Tall. Also, its neck & head look like a "7" and its body like a "6".
**Ir**idescent Rainbow. 7 Colors in a rainbow (77). Iris was the Greek goddess of the rainbow.
Platinum Record. The old kind that rotated at a speed of 78 rpm. Recorded by "The Egy**pt**ians". A platinum recording soldmore copies than a gold, and platinum is worth more than gold.
Gold Coin. A '79 **A.U.** (Almost Uncirculated). The latin word for gold is aurum.
**H**igh-**g**rade Thermometer. Showing 80 degrees.
Tallow Candle. 81. Looks like a "1" and sounds like "tallow". Used in cas**tl**es.
Lead Plumbing. Under the cu**pb**oard. 82% lead. The latin word for lead is plumbum.
Pepto **Bi**smol. I "ate 3" teaspoons of Pepto Bismol (sounds like "83"). Pepto Bismol contains Bismuth Subsalicylate.
**Po**lo Stick. 7 dozen (84) polo sticks.
**A t**all Aster (85 petals). The flowers, stem and leaf form an "85".
Radar wa**rn**ing. Protection for 86 miles.
**Fr**ance's Eiffel Tower. Built for the World's Fair and commemorated the centenniel of the French Revolution which technically began in 17**87**.
**Ra**dio. Piano music (88 keys) on FM 88.
**Ac**tor. He won 89 oscars.
**Th**orn. Thorns stick out at 90° angle.
**Pa**per protractor. Measuring 91°, one degree more than a right angle. Use it to measure the angle of the thorns next to it.
**U**ranium A-Bomb. 92 Kilotons. Memorize Uranus, Neptune and Pluto (the planets in a row) for 92, 93, 94.
Neptunia**n p**itchfork. Neptune's trident is 9' long with 3 prongs. Memorize Uranus, Neptune and Pluto (the planets in a row) for 92, 93, 94.
Pluto the **Pu**p. Mickey Mouse's dog. Memorize Uranus, Neptune and Pluto (the planets in a row) for 92, 93, 94, and remember that Pluto's ears look like a "94".
**Am**erican flag. Cost $95.
A**cm**e's curious curtains. For a standard 8-foot tall room (96").
Ri**b k**nit Beret. '97 style. Named for Berkeley, California, where berets have been seen.
**C**auli-**f**lower. Remember Berkeley, California, are consecutiveand that there is a 98 hidden in the cauliflower. California produces a lot of cauliflower.
Einstein's **es**oteric earrings. The hidden meaning is that his theory predicts you can only go 99% of the speed of light.
**F**ur **m**ink. "Fur" sounds like fermium. It cost 100 thousand dollars and is 100% real fur from mink.
Mental **M.D.**. They work on brains. Mental MD's alltook Psychology 101.
**No** Bell. The red bar divides the picture into two parts, to remember 102.
Laurel Wreath. It has 103 leaves, and this one was also made with bu**lr**ushes.
Ruth's pe**rf**ect Ford. It has 4 wheels and Ford sounds like"four" to remember 104. The Model-T was so "perfect" that is was popular for many years.
